title: 107_hr4037
content: The Act titled "Central American Security Act" allows for the adjustment of status for certain nationals from El Salvador, Guatemala, and Honduras. The Nicaraguan Adjustment and Central American Relief Act is amended to include nationals from El Salvador, Guatemala, and Honduras in addition to Nicaraguans and Cubans. The changes involve adjusting dates related to the implementation of the Central American Security Act. SEC. 3. APPLICATIONS PENDING UNDER AMENDMENTS MADE BY SECTION 203 OF THE NICARAGUAN ADJUSTMENT AND CENTRAL AMERICAN RELIEF ACT. An application for relief filed by a national of Guatemala or El Salvador under the amendments made by section 203 of the Nicaraguan Adjustment and Central American Relief Act before the enactment of this Act can be considered for adjustment of status under section 202 of the same Act, upon payment of fees and compliance with prescribed procedures by the Attorney General. Refunds for fees paid in connection with such applications are not allowed. Technical amendments to the Nicaraguan Adjustment and Central American Relief Act are also included. The Nicaraguan Adjustment and Central American Relief Act is amended to allow the Attorney General to waive grounds of inadmissibility for humanitarian purposes, family unity, or public interest. It also addresses the relationship of applications to certain orders for aliens present in the United States. The Nicaraguan Adjustment and Central American Relief Act allows aliens to apply for adjustment of status despite deportation orders, without needing to file separate motions. The Attorney General can deny stays or adjustment applications, making deportation orders enforceable. The Attorney General can deny stays or adjustment applications, making deportation orders enforceable for aliens applying for adjustment of status under the Nicaraguan Adjustment and Central American Relief Act. The Central American Security Act amends the adjustment of status for spouses, children, and unmarried sons and daughters of aliens in the United States. The Central American Security Act modifies the adjustment of status for spouses, children, and unmarried sons and daughters of aliens in the United States, with specific provisions regarding age requirements and filing for adjustment. The Central American Security Act requires proof of qualifying marriage before enactment date and physical presence in the US since December 1, 1995 for unmarried sons or daughters applying for adjustment of status. The application for adjustment under this subsection is filed when a principal alien filed for adjustment under subsection (a) or pursuant to the amendments made by section 203, and the status of the principal alien is adjusted to that of an alien lawfully admitted for permanent residence. Upon approval of an application for adjustment of status to that of an alien lawfully admitted for permanent residence, an alien's spouse or child may be issued a visa to join the principal applicant in the United States as an immigrant. The Secretary of State may retain fees to cover the cost of processing immigrant visa applications for spouses and children of approved adjustment of status applicants. Fees collected will offset Department of State expenses. The amendments made by paragraphs (1)(B), (2), and (6) in the section authorize the Secretary of State to retain fees for processing immigrant visa applications and support consular activities. The amendments also clarify that no alien can apply for admission or adjustment of status without the authorization of the Attorney General. The amendments made by paragraphs (1)(A), (3), (4), and (5) will take effect upon the enactment of this Act, while paragraph (6) will be retroactively effective as if included in the Nicaraguan Adjustment and Central American Relief Act. SEC. 5. SECURITY AND CRIMINAL BACKGROUND INVESTIGATIONS. Applicants for relief under this Act must undergo security and criminal background investigations. Fingerprints must be submitted for processing. SEC. 6. MOTIONS TO REOPEN. SEC. 6. MOTIONS TO REOPEN. A national of Cuba or Nicaragua with a final denial of adjustment of status under the Nicaraguan Adjustment and Central American Relief Act can file one motion to reopen within 180 days of this Act's enactment to have their application reconsidered. The scope of the proceeding is limited to determining eligibility for adjustment of status under the Act.
